articles.headline: Pay Rules Adopted by S.E.C.
articles.snippet: The commission adopted new rules to make it easier to see executives salaries and to discourage the manipulation of stock option grants.
articles.abstract: The commission adopted new rules to make it easier to see executives salaries and to discourage the manipulation of stock option grants.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday adopted a sweeping set of new rules to make it easier to see how much top executives are paid and to discourage the manipulation of stock option grants.

articles.headline: Cease-Fire Talks Stall as Fighting Rages on 2 Fronts
articles.snippet: Israel’s two-front conflict had its heaviest day of fighting, killing 9 Israeli soldiers, dozens of Hezbollah fighters and at least 23 Palestinians in Gaza.
articles.abstract: Israel’s two-front conflict had its heaviest day of fighting, killing 9 Israeli soldiers, dozens of Hezbollah fighters and at least 23 Palestinians in Gaza.
articles.lead_paragraph: AVIVIM, Israel, July 26 — Israel’s two-front conflict saw its heaviest day of fighting on Wednesday, killing 9 Israeli soldiers, dozens of Hezbollah fighters and at least 23 Palestinians in Gaza. As the battles raged, a meeting of the United States and European and Arab countries in Rome failed to reach agreement on a plan to end the fighting between Israel and Hezbollah as the United States resisted calls for an immediate cease-fire.
articles.byline: By Craig S. Smith and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Chicago Orders ‘Big Box’ Stores to Raise Wage
articles.snippet: A groundbreaking measure requires stores like Wal-Mart and Home Depot to pay $10 an hour by 2010.
articles.abstract: A groundbreaking measure requires stores like Wal-Mart and Home Depot to pay $10 an hour by 2010.
articles.lead_paragraph: After months of fevered lobbying and bitter debate, the Chicago City Council passed a groundbreaking ordinance yesterday requiring “big box” stores, like Wal-Mart and Home Depot, to pay a minimum wage of $10 an hour by 2010, along with at least $3 an hour worth of benefits.

articles.headline: Enough Anger to Make Ketchup Boil
articles.snippet: Shareholders will vote on whether to back Heinz’s current board or install the activist investor Nelson Peltz’s five-member slate.
articles.abstract: Shareholders will vote on whether to back Heinz’s current board or install the activist investor Nelson Peltz’s five-member slate.

articles.headline: Operations at G.M. Post Profit
articles.snippet: Over all, the company lost $3.1 billion in the second quarter, including a raft of charges related to restructuring.
articles.abstract: Over all, the company lost $3.1 billion in the second quarter, including a raft of charges related to restructuring.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Motors says its surprising second-quarter operating profit proves that its turnaround is off and running. Analysts counter that it still has not tackled its fundamental problem: sliding market share.

articles.headline: Failure of Global Trade Talks Is Traced to the Power of Farmers
articles.snippet: The collapse of the talks demonstrated the power of farmers in resisting lower agricultural tariffs and subsidies.
articles.abstract: The collapse of the talks demonstrated the power of farmers in resisting lower agricultural tariffs and subsidies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 26  For months, the Bush administration had tirelessly warned farmers to prepare for the possibility of a global trade deal. At the Indiana State Fair last year, Charles F. Conner, the deputy agriculture secretary, told listeners not to expect “anything close” to the subsidies they had been used to for decades.
articles.byline: By Steven R. Weisman and Alexei Barrionuevo

articles.headline: For Israeli Unit, Hezbollah Lair Is Ambush Site
articles.snippet: The details of the battle for Bint Jbail, Lebanon, show how difficult it could be for Israel to drive Hezbollah from southern Lebanon.
articles.abstract: The details of the battle for Bint Jbail, Lebanon, show how difficult it could be for Israel to drive Hezbollah from southern Lebanon.
articles.lead_paragraph: AVIVIM, Israel, July 26 — Two days ago, Israeli officers along the border were saying that they were in control of Bint Jbail, the biggest Hezbollah stronghold within easy striking distance across the border and an important symbolic target. Hezbollah’s leader, Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, celebrated Israel’s withdrawal from southern Lebanon with a parade there six years ago.

articles.headline: Cease-Fire Talks Stall as Fighting Rages on 2 Fronts
articles.snippet: Israel's two-front conflict saw its heaviest day of fighting on Wednesday, killing 9 Israeli soldiers, dozens of Hezbollah fighters and at least 23 Palestinians in Gaza. As the battles raged, a meeting of the United States and European and Arab co...
articles.abstract: Israel's two-front conflict saw its heaviest day of fighting on Wednesday, killing 9 Israeli soldiers, dozens of Hezbollah fighters and at least 23 Palestinians in Gaza. As the battles raged, a meeting of the United States and European and Arab countries in Rome failed to reach agreement on a plan to end the fighting between Israel and Hezbollah as the United States resisted calls for an immediate cease-fire.      Hezbollah kept up its sustained fire on northern Israel, with 130 rockets hitting the region, wounding more than 10 Israelis.
articles.lead_paragraph: AVIVIM, Israel, July 26 - Israel's two-front conflict saw its heaviest day of fighting on Wednesday, killing 9 Israeli soldiers, dozens of Hezbollah fighters and at least 23 Palestinians in Gaza. As the battles raged, a meeting of the United States and European and Arab countries in Rome failed to reach agreement on a plan to end the fighting between Israel and Hezbollah as the United States resisted calls for an immediate cease-fire.
articles.byline: By Craig S. Smith and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: For Israeli Unit, Hezbollah Lair Is Ambush Site
articles.snippet: Two days ago, Israeli officers along the border were saying that they were in control of Bint Jbail, the biggest Hezbollah stronghold within easy striking distance across the border and an important symbolic target. Hezbollah's leader, Sheik Hassa...
articles.abstract: Two days ago, Israeli officers along the border were saying that they were in control of Bint Jbail, the biggest Hezbollah stronghold within easy striking distance across the border and an important symbolic target. Hezbollah's leader, Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, celebrated Israel's withdrawal from southern Lebanon with a parade there six years ago.     But when Israel sent in its elite Golani Infantry Brigade to secure the town before dawn on Wednesday, hundreds of soldiers were quickly pinned down by a Hezbollah ambush. Eight soldiers were killed almost immediately, and it took until early afternoon to move the dead and wounded two miles under heavy fire to a safe spot where they were picked up by helicopter and flown to a hospital in Haifa.
articles.lead_paragraph: AVIVIM, Israel, July 26 - Two days ago, Israeli officers along the border were saying that they were in control of Bint Jbail, the biggest Hezbollah stronghold within easy striking distance across the border and an important symbolic target. Hezbollah's leader, Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, celebrated Israel's withdrawal from southern Lebanon with a parade there six years ago.

articles.headline: Failure of Global Trade Talks Is Traced to the Power of Farmers
articles.snippet: For months, the Bush administration had tirelessly warned farmers to prepare for the possibility of a global trade deal. At the Indiana State Fair last year, Charles F. Conner, the deputy agriculture secretary, told listeners not to expect ''anyth...
articles.abstract: For months, the Bush administration had tirelessly warned farmers to prepare for the possibility of a global trade deal. At the Indiana State Fair last year, Charles F. Conner, the deputy agriculture secretary, told listeners not to expect ''anything close'' to the subsidies they had been used to for decades.     But the collapse of world trade talks this week has again proved that a small number of farmers in the United States -- as well as Europe, Japan, India and other trading partners -- have the power to resist lower agricultural tariffs and subsidies, even though a global trade deal might ultimately benefit most of them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 26 - For months, the Bush administration had tirelessly warned farmers to prepare for the possibility of a global trade deal. At the Indiana State Fair last year, Charles F. Conner, the deputy agriculture secretary, told listeners not to expect "anything close" to the subsidies they had been used to for decades.
articles.byline: By Steven R. Weisman and Alexei Barrionuevo

articles.headline: Enough Anger to Make Ketchup Boil
articles.snippet: Nelson Peltz was agitated.     In three decades as an activist investor -- or to others, corporate raider -- Mr. Peltz has been called many things, but he was clearly flustered in a recent phone interview when told that the chief executive of Hein...
articles.abstract: Nelson Peltz was agitated.     In three decades as an activist investor -- or to others, corporate raider -- Mr. Peltz has been called many things, but he was clearly flustered in a recent phone interview when told that the chief executive of Heinz had accused him of copying his own strategy for the company from Heinz's overhaul plan.

articles.headline: Odd Bedfellows Align to Market Oliver Stone's Film About 9/11
articles.snippet: Oliver Stone, that symbol of everything about Hollywood that conservatives love to hate, is getting help in marketing his newest movie from an unlikely ally: the publicity firm that helped devise the Swift boat campaign attacking John Kerry's Viet...
articles.abstract: Oliver Stone, that symbol of everything about Hollywood that conservatives love to hate, is getting help in marketing his newest movie from an unlikely ally: the publicity firm that helped devise the Swift boat campaign attacking John Kerry's Vietnam record in the 2004 presidential race.     And so Mr. Stone, the director of the antiwar movies ''Platoon'' and ''Born on the Fourth of July,'' now finds himself sharing something in common with a group of Vietnam veterans who insisted that their comrades who demonstrated against the war were misguided, misled or traitorous.

articles.headline: Chicago Orders Big Box Stores to Raise Wage
articles.snippet: After months of fevered lobbying and bitter debate, the Chicago City Council passed a groundbreaking ordinance yesterday requiring ''big box'' stores, like Wal-Mart and Home Depot, to pay a minimum wage of $10 an hour by 2010, along with at least ...
articles.abstract: After months of fevered lobbying and bitter debate, the Chicago City Council passed a groundbreaking ordinance yesterday requiring ''big box'' stores, like Wal-Mart and Home Depot, to pay a minimum wage of $10 an hour by 2010, along with at least $3 an hour worth of benefits.      The ordinance, imposing the requirement on stores that occupy more than 90,000 square feet and are part of companies grossing more than $1 billion annually, would be the first in the country to single out large retailers for wage rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: After months of fevered lobbying and bitter debate, the Chicago City Council passed a groundbreaking ordinance yesterday requiring "big box" stores, like Wal-Mart and Home Depot, to pay a minimum wage of $10 an hour by 2010, along with at least $3 an hour worth of benefits.

articles.headline: Pay Rules Adopted by S.E.C.
articles.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday adopted a sweeping set of new rules to make it easier to see how much top executives are paid and to discourage the manipulation of stock option grants.     With a unanimous vote, the five S.E.C. co...
articles.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday adopted a sweeping set of new rules to make it easier to see how much top executives are paid and to discourage the manipulation of stock option grants.     With a unanimous vote, the five S.E.C. commissioners set in motion a plan that calls for companies to describe more clearly how their executives are compensated and to provide new information, like the lump-sum cost of retirement benefits and explanations of why specific stock option grants were approved. The rules will go into effect in mid-December, several months ahead of proxy season next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday adopted a sweeping set of new rules to make it easier to see how much top executives are paid and to discourage the manipulation of stock option grants.

articles.headline: Operations at G.M. Post Profit
articles.snippet: General Motors says its surprising second-quarter operating profit proves that its turnaround is off and running. Analysts counter that it still has not tackled its fundamental problem: sliding market share.     Over all, G.M. reported yesterday t...
articles.abstract: General Motors says its surprising second-quarter operating profit proves that its turnaround is off and running. Analysts counter that it still has not tackled its fundamental problem: sliding market share.     Over all, G.M. reported yesterday that it lost $3.1 billion in the second quarter, including a raft of one-time charges related to the restructuring in North America, where it continued to lose money last quarter. But investors were pleased by G.M.'s adjusted profit of $1.1 billion, or $2.03 a share, in the second quarter, a big swing from an adjusted loss of $235 million, or 41 cents a share, in the comparable period last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Motors says its surprising second-quarter operating profit proves that its turnaround is off and running. Analysts counter that it still has not tackled its fundamental problem: sliding market share.
